Claim: UK carbon dioxide emissions have fallen 42% since 1990.
Justifications: The percentage decrease in emissions and minimum annual value supports the dataset description. The UK emmission trends from 1990 to 2019.

The claim that UK carbon dioxide emissions fell by 42% since 1990 is broadly correct. Between 1990 and 2019, emissions dropped from about 602 million tonnes to around 365 million tonnes, which is a 39.4% decrease (not 42%). The claim was made in January 2020, and at that time, the most recent data was from 2019. While it’s true that emissions went down in most of those years, the percentage in the claim is higher than what the data shows.

Claim: Best available data show sea-level rise is not accelerating.
Claimant: Craig Idso, Robert Carter, S. Fred Singer
Justifications: The data shows a gradual acceleration of the sea level rising from 1930 onward. Change values from 2000 to 2017 and 2010 and 2015 also show much larger shifts.

The facts do not support the claim. From roughly 0.76 mm/yr (1900–1930) to over 3.3 mm/yr since 1993, the data indicates clear acceleration in the average yearly rate of sea-level rise over time. At 3.36 mm/yr, the rate stayed high even between 2000 and 2017—much faster than rates in past 20th centuries.

The claim is refuted because from 1900 to 1930, the sea level accelerated by 22.79 mm, with an average yearly increase of approximately 0.76 mm per year. During the shorter period from 2000 to 2017, the sea level increased by 57.17mm, which is not as claimed.

Claim: We [the UK] have cut our greenhouse-gas emissions by 44% in the last 30 years while expanding our GDP by 78%.

Claim: Sea levels are rising negligibly or decreasing in various locations.

The claim that “sea levels are rising negligibly or decreasing in various locations” is inaccurate because long-term global data clearly show a consistent and significant increase in sea level over time. Claim: In 2019 the United States "led the world" in reducing carbon dioxide emissions.

Although U.S. emissions fell by about 115 million tonnes (a 2.1% drop) between 2018-2019, the EU reduced emissions by about 144 million tonnes (a 4.7% drop), which is both a larger absolute and relative decrease. Similarly, Japan’s emissions declined by about 3.2% over the same period.

Claim: Germany has not reduced emissions in the past decade.

The claim that "Germany has not reduced emissions in the past decade" (as of June 2022) is refuted by multiple data sources showing consistent declines in both greenhouse gas (GHG) and CO₂ emissions:

2009–2019 Decade:

GHG emissions fell by 10.66% (888.5M → 793.8M tonnes).

CO₂ emissions fell by 10.14% (790.0M → 709.8M tonnes).

2012–2021 Decade:

GHG emissions fell by 16.64% (910.6M → 759.0M tonnes), with the steepest drops occurring in 2019–2021.

Trend Analysis:

The 10-year average emissions were lower than 2009 levels, confirming a sustained decline.

The largest reductions happened recently (e.g., 2019), contradicting any suggestion of stagnation.

The claim was refuted because between 2009 and 2019, Germany's greenhouse gas emissions fell 10.66% which is from 888.5 million to 793.8 million tonnes, and also CO₂ emissions specifically fell 10.14% in the same period.

Claim: Income Inequality [in the USA] grew to largest in 50 years.
Justifications: Based on the data from the charts and tables, the Gini coefficient in 2019 was 0.42, its highest value every recorded. Likewise, the US Atkinson index in 2019 was 0.27, which matched its highest recorded value ever.

The U.S. Gini coefficient in 2019 was 0.42, the highest recorded value between 1969 and 2019, showing that income inequality reached its largest level in 50 years. The Gini rose from 0.36 in 1969 to 0.42 in 2019, confirming long-term growth in inequality. While the share of electricity generation is not reaching 95%, 91.91% is close enough to the claimed figure, given that the claimant said "almost 95%".

Claim: Cows are a major source of greenhouse gas emissions.

In 2021, agriculture-related methane emissions were 3.55 billion tonnes CO2e out of 52.92 billion tonnes total global greenhouse gases—about 6.7% of all GHG that year (1990–2021). 6.7% is far from being a "major" source.

 Comparing period averages, production rose from 136.093 MT (2011–2014) to 160.752 MT (2014–2017)—about +24.659 MT (~18%), not 12%.

The claim is refuted because, both wind and and solar power have contributed more than two per cent fin the  years 2021 and 2022.  In the year 2021 the wind and solar power contributed to 21.68 % of electricity and in 2022 contributed 24.76% of electricity in Australia.

Even individually, wind and solar each exceeded 10% in both years. This shows that the claim of wind and solar contributing less than 2% is false.

Claim: Democrats, including President Joe Biden, “stopped domestic drilling” for oil.

Claim: Says the United States has doubled our use of renewable energy.

Claim: We [USA] end up spending as a nation twice as much per capita on health care as do the people of any other country.

Claim: [There has been] a global boost in cereal production over the last 60 years.
Justifications: This claim is supported by the evidence based on the +276.78% increase from the years 1963-2023. In addition, the average annual output was 1.89 billion tonnes which is very comparable to the minimum amount of 831 million tonnes in 1963.
The data supports an consistent upward trend year to year of a global boost in cereal production over the last 60 years.

The claim is supported. Global cereal production has rose from 832 million to 3.13 billion tonnes. Both the statements and the dataset backs up the claim. And it shows a much higher output now than 60 years ago so providing facts to the claim of a global boost in cereal production.

Claim: As president, Donald Trump “marshaled the full power of government to stop deadly drugs, opioids, and fentanyl from coming into our country. As a result, drug overdose deaths declined nationwide for the first time in nearly 30 years."
Justifications: The claim that drug overdose deaths declined under Trump is misleading: overall deaths increased significantly from 2017 to 2020, contradicting assertions of a nationwide drop in nearly 30 years.

The claim is false. Overdose deaths did fall slightly in 2018, but they rose again in 2019 and hit record highs in 2020. Also, declines had happened before 2018 for cocaine and other drugs, so it was not the first drop in nearly 30 years.

Claim: I want China to do well [in economic growth], and I hope they do well, but they’ve had now the worst year in 57 years.
Justifications: The claim is refuted by the data. Although China's GDP growth was 6.07%, lower than the period average of 9.48% from 1962-2019, a lower rate was experienced in 1990 at 3.89%
The claim that China had the worst year in 57 years in 2019 is not true. Growth was lower in 1990.

Claim: China doesn’t have a lot of wind farms. … Very, very few.
Justifications: China's wind power capacity grew to 521.27 GW by 2024, contradicting the claim.

The claim is refuted, because in 2024 (the latest available year), China's installed wind capacity was 521.27 GW and wind generation was 991.60 TWh. Wind power consumption per person in China was 1,713.36 kWh in 2024, up from 95.18 kWh in 2010.

The claim says China doesn't have many wind farms, but the data shows the opposite. By 2024, China had over 521 GW of installed capacity and produced nearly 992 TWh from wind, far more than "very few." Per capita consumption rose sharply, and China led global wind power growth. The evidence clearly contradicts the claim.

Claim: [Kenya's] GDP growth improved from 4.9% in 2022 to 5.6% in 2023 …
Claimant: Kenyan president William Ruto’s scorecard published by the state-owned MyGov weekly
Justifications: The claim is supported by reported data. GDP growth of 4.86% in 2022 and 5.56% in 2023- matches the rounded figures cited in the claim. These numbers show an improvement in GDP growth for that period.
This is correct. The GDP growth in Kenya increased to 5.56 in 2023 compared to 4.86 in 2022 and this corresponds to 4.9 and 5.6 respectively.

The claim is supported, because Kenya's GDP growth wsa 4.86% in 2022 and 5.56% in 2023, which is 4.9% and 5.6% when rounded. The GDP increased by 0.70 percentage points (+14.32%), indicating a clear growth improvement.
The claim is supported and the data shows that Kenya's GDP growth improved from 4.9% in 2022 to 5.6% in 2023.

Claim: [India's] capture fish production increased from 186.18 lakh tonnes during 2012-14 to 210.2 lakh tonnes during 2014-16.
Justifications: This claim is refuted due to the fact that the period totals of 145.60 lakh t in 2012-14 and 150.58 lakh t in 2014-16 are below the values in the claim that stated 186.18 lakh t in 2012-14 and 210.2 lakh t in 2014-16.

The period totals in this capture-fishery dataset (145.60 lakh t in 2012–14; 150.58 lakh t in 2014–16) are far below the claim’s 186.18 and 210.2 lakh t, so the specific amounts are not supported here.

Claim: We [Australia] are spending record amounts on hospitals, we are spending record amounts on health.
Justifications:
The data graphs support all of the claims:

In 2018, Australia’s health spending per person was 5,331.51
per‑person health spending rose by 3,180.17 (+147.82%)
Government health spending was 7.19% of GDP in 2018, slightly below the series peak of 7.23% in 2015
The largest annual jump in per‑person health spending was in 2014 (+500.14, +12.0%)
Australia is spending records amount on health and that is supported by evidence as the spending was $5331.51 per person health in 2018 which is a record, so this claim made in 2018 is supported.

Claim: [Russian's economic] development continues here ... Despite the difficult times, the country is developing and will continue to develop.
Justifications: From 2000-2022, Russia's average annual GDP growth was 3.34%, with a cumulative total of 76.77 across those years. However, during those same years, Russia had 13 years of GDP decline and only 9 years of growth. Although the claim was made before the end of 2022, Russia's GDP had fallen 1.44% that year, after growing 5.87% in 2021. So, there was some cherry picking of data to make this claim since there have been periods of both growth and decline over those years.

The claim suggests ongoing economic development despite challenges. However, GDP fell by 1.44% in 2022, marking a sharp reversal from 2021. Over the longer period, Russia experienced more years of decline than growth, undermining the claim of consistent development. This seems like using cherry-picked data to make a claim.

Claim: Statistics show the gap in [the UK's] income inequality is narrowing.
Justifications: The claim is supported. From the statements to the datasets it does show that the Gini coefficient from 0.39 in 2000 to 0.33. The lower the number less income equality. Atkinson index also from from 0.19 in 2010 to 0.17 in 2016. So this substantiates the claim that the income equality is narrowing.

For the period 2010-2016, the Gini coefficient fell from 0.337 in 2000 to 0.331 in 2016, and the Atkinson index fell from 0.188 in 2010 to 0.171 in 2016.
We don't have earlier data for the Atkinson index, but we have data for the Gini coefficient. Between 2000 and 2016, the Gini coefficient fell from 0.388 in 2000 to 0.331 in 2016, a -14.7% decline.

Given both measures, we can say that the inequality gap has narrowed, making this claim true.

Claim: Honduras ... has the "highest homicide rate in the entire world." Switzerland ... has the "lowest homicide rate in the entire world."
Justifications: The evidence clearly shows that Honduras did not have the highest homicide rate in 2014 or 2015; El Salvador’s rate was higher in both years. Similarly, Switzerland did not have the lowest homicide rate in 2015, as both Japan and smaller microstates like San Marino and Monaco had lower rates. Therefore, the claim that Honduras is the world’s highest and Switzerland the world’s lowest is incorrect.

In 2015, Honduras had about 67.7 homicide deaths per 100,000 people (6,249.35 deaths; population 9,237,261), while El Salvador had about 89.6 per 100,000 (5,536.78 deaths; population 6,183,621), so Honduras did not have the highest rate.

Claim: Today, eight out of 10 South Africans have electricity in their homes.
Justifications: The evidence clearly shows that more than 80% of South Africans had access to electricity in 2018 and 2019, with 85% in 2019 specifically. This directly supports President Ramaphosa’s claim that “eight out of 10 South Africans have electricity in their homes.”

The datasets show that between 2018 and 2019, 84.70–85.00% of South Africans had electricity access, consistently above the 80% threshold stated in the claim, confirming that “eight out of 10” is accurate.

Claim: ... homophobic views declined in countries around the world from 1993 to 2022.
Justifications: The claim is supported because the number of share that saying they do not want homosexuals as neighbors fell sharply in the years 1993 - 2022.

This is true. From 1993 to 2022, the share saying they would not want homosexual neighbors fell substantially in multiple countries: United Kingdom 31.12%→4.28%, Germany 34.31%→7.48%, and Brazil 30.22%→6.78%. In the same time period, those saying homosexuality is “never or rarely justified” also dropped steeply: Japan 71.81%→17.89%, Spain 56.04%→19.08%, and Canada 52.33%→11.41%.

Claim: The United States is "#1 in oil consumption" in the world.
Justifications: The evidence clearly shows that the United States had the highest oil consumption in the world for both 2018 and 2019, consistently ranking #1 ahead of China. Total, average, and yearly consumption data all support the claim that the U.S. is the leading oil consumer.

In 2019, the United States had the highest oil consumption at 10,287.68 TWh, ahead of China’s 7,891.51 TWh, ranking first.
In 2018, the United States also led with 10,303.76 TWh, exceeding China’s 7,528.74 TWh.
Rankings show the United States was #1 in both 2018 and 2019, while China was #2 in both years.
Source: Oil consumption (2018–2019)
In 2019, the United States had the highest oil consumption at 10,287.68 TWh, ahead of China’s 7,891.51 TWh, ranking first.

Claim: We [Kenya] have grown … our power generation 40 times.
Justifications: This claim is refuted due to the fact that the 40 times power generation from 8.08 TWh in the year 2013 would be approximately 323.2 TWh which should be in the year 2021. But it is in fact not 323.2 TWh and instead it was 12.38 TWh for the year 2021. In addition, if claim for the percentage increase, it was only 53.22% increase which is not the 40x power generation that the statement claimed.

The claim is refuted, because from 2013-2021, Kenya's total electricity generation increased about 1.53 times, not 40 times. Total electricity generation was 8.08 TWh in 2013, and 12.38 TWh in 2021, the latest year before the June 2022 claim. A fortyfold increase would be about 323 TWh, not the actual 12.38 TWh that the provided data indicates.

Claim: If wind and solar power were the answer, China would be building them at record speed. Instead they’re increasing their use of coal.
Justifications: The claim is refuted because, China shows a significant decline by -46.6 %  in the use of coal in the years 2023 and 2024 and increase in the use of solar power wind power.

While it's true that China’s coal consumption rose from 25,181.21 TWh in 2023 to 25,599.31 TWh in 2024 (+418.10 TWh, +1.66%), it is not true that China is not building wind and solar:

China’s total wind capacity rose from 441.89 GW to 521.27 GW from 2023 to 2024—up 79.37 GW (+17.96%).
China’s total solar capacity grew from 609.92 GW in 2023 to 887.10 GW in 2024—an increase of 277.18 GW (+45.45%).

Also, using the annual change consumption data, we can see that while China's increase in coal use was +783.43 TWh in 2023, this number dropped to +418.10 TWh in 2024, which is about −46.6% annual decrease.

Therefore, this claim is refuted.

Claim: 47.3% of Nigerians were multidimensionally poor in 2021.
Justifications: The claim is refuted. The evidence clearly contradicts the claim since the multidimensional poor Nigerians in 2021 was 33.04% compared to the claimed 47.3%.
This claim is refuted due to the fact that the reported Nigerians that were multidimensionally poor in 2021 was 33.04% instead of the claim of 47.30%.
The claim is false because in 2021 only 33% of Nigerians were multidimensionally poor, not 47%.

According to the assertion, the 2021 multidimensional poverty rate among Nigerians was 47.3 percent. The dataset indicates that the population that was multidimensionally poor that year was at 33.04% which is quite less than the assertion. This implies that the assertion inflates the real amount by 14.26 percentage points. Thus, the evidence is refuting the argument.
According to the source, 33.04% of Nigeria's population was multidimensionally poor. This is 14.26% lower than the original claim. The claim is refuted.
The dataset confirms that 33.04% of Nigerians were multidimensionally poor in 2021, not 47.3% as claimed, meaning the claim exaggerates the true figure by more than 14 percentage points.

Claim: In the United States alone we lose more than 3,000 people a day to cancer.
Justifications: The data does not support the claim that in the United States alone we lose more than 3,000 people a day to cancer.
In 2016, the United States had an estimated 611,315.70 deaths from malignant neoplasms—about 1,675 per day on average—well under 3,000 per day.

Claim: The United States has “dropped off” a list of the 20 most democratic countries in the world.
Justifications: The evidence demonstrate that there is, in fact, evidence that the United States fell out of the top 20 most democratic nations by 2018. In 2015 the U.S. was 6th and in 2018 the score was 0.82 or 32nd. On the contrary, the 20th ranked nation, Italy, scored 0.87 that year. The steady decline that was witnessed in the U.S. over the period between 2015 and 2018 also attests to the fact that it was no longer in the top 20.
In 2018, Italy held the 20th spot with a score of 0.87, while the United States was 32nd at 0.82, confirming it was not in the top 20 that year. Supports the claim.

The evidence in the datasets does support the claim. In 2015, the United States was ranked 6th on the list of most democratic countries. In 2017 and 2018, the United States was not among the top 20 most democratic countries. (It was closer to 30th place.)

Claim: A World Health Organization report: "More people are dying of TB."
Justifications: The data does not support the claim that more people are dying of TB.  The data reflects the exact opposite that each consecutive year from 2006 to 2016 showed a decline in deaths.

The claim is refuted, because worldwide TB deaths decreased from 2,319,746 (2006) to 1,545,608 (2016), which is a reduction of 33.37% (774,138 fewer deaths). Each consecutive year between 2006 and 2016 showed a decline in deaths and no years of growth.

Claim: Former president Mwai Kibaki [president of Kenya 2002–2013] raised GDP growth to 7%.
Justifications: The claim is conflicting because, in these period in the year 2010 the GDP was 8.06 % surpassing the claimed 7% but also in the year 2013 the GDP growth was at 3.79 % which is below the claimed 7%. The average growth in 2002 to 2013 was 4.29% which is below the claimed 7%.

Kibaki was the president of Kenya from 2002 to 2013.

Given the "Annual GDP growth" data, we can observe the following facts:
Between 2002–2013, Kenya’s annual GDP growth peaked at 8.06% in 2010, surpassing the 7% level cited in the claim.
The average growth over 2002–2013 was 4.29%, below 7%, indicating 7% was not typical for this period.
By 2013, the growth rate was 3.80%, below 7%, so any 7%+ rate was not maintained through the end of the period.

Thus, while it is true that the annual GDP growth reached 7% at some point during this time period, the overall growth was much lower during Kibaki’s presidency. Therefore, this claim seems like cherry-picking.

The claim likely overstates the typical growth rate during Kibaki’s presidency (2002–2013), focusing on a peak value (8.06% in 2010) and ignoring the fact that the average growth rate for the entire period was much lower. Therefore, the claim can be considered misleading or cherry-picked, as it highlights a singular high point and ignores the broader, less impressive growth performance. A more accurate statement would be that Kenya saw periods of relatively strong growth during Kibaki’s time, but not consistently at or above 7% for the full period.

Claim: The average rate of growth of the [Uganda's] economy ever since 1986 has been 6.3% per annum.
Justifications: The argument, that the Uganda economy has been expanding at an average rate of 6.3 percent per annum since 1986, is somewhat exaggerated. The real growth rate of the years 1986 to 2018 is 6.23 which is only 0.07 percentage points different. Though the statement is a bit rounded off, the facts indicate that the real number is slightly less. Generally, the statement is almost accurate but not entirely true.

The claim is almost accurate.

Over 1986–2018, Uganda’s average annual real GDP growth is reported as 6.23%, not 6.3% as claimed.
The claim overstates the period average by 0.07 percentage points (6.3% vs 6.23%) for 1986–2018.

Based on the data reviewed, the claim is 0.07% higher than the data and falls within a reasonable margin of error.

Claim: Nigeria has more people living in multidimensional poverty than India.
Justifications: The claim is not supported. It is contradicted by the fact that 227.7 million Indians lived in multidimensional poverty in 2019, while 72.21 million Nigerians faced poverty in 2021.

In 2019, India had 16.39% of its 1,389,030,252 people living in multidimensional poverty—about 227.7 million individuals.
In 2021, Nigeria had 33.04% of its 218,529,237 people living in multidimensional poverty—about 72.21 million individuals.

While the dataset doesn't provide figures for the exact same year, this difference is significant enough to refute the claim, especially considering that we're only looking at a 2-year gap.

Claim: Since 1961, Africa has witnessed a one-third reduction in agricultural productivity due to climate change.
Justifications: The argument that the agricultural productivity in Africa declined by a third since 1961 because of the climatic changes is not supported by the statistics. First, the data shows no values of Africa during the period of 1961-1990, therefore, the changes since 1961 cannot be measured. Between 1991 and 2022, the agricultural value added per worker actually grew at 61,558.28 to 178,597.22 or an increase of +190.13 not a decrease. Peak productivity is being verified by the high of 178,863.59 in 2021. The biggest single year decline was only -5.4 the following year in 1992 which is nowhere near the one third cut. Besides, there are no climate clues in the dataset and therefore, the argument that any change is due to climate is not substantiated.
The data contain no values for 1961–1990. Hard to support the claim with the given information.

Claim: The range of freedom of speech actually practiced in Russia is greater than anywhere else on the planet.
Justifications: The argument is that Russia boasts the widest freedom of speech across the world. Nonetheless, the statistics indicate that the freedom-of-expression rating in Russia in 2019 amounted to 4 (rank 82), which is significantly lower than in a number of countries that got 10. Its score on civil liberties, as well as liberal democracy were also extremely poor in comparison with such countries as Finland, Norway, Sweden, Denmark, and Switzerland. These indexes show that Russia does not have the freedom of speech and civil liberties but rather the lowest in the world.

Russia consistently scores significantly lower than countries recognized as liberal democracies across various metrics.
Russia's freedom-of-expression score in 2019 was 4, ranking 82nd, while several countries scored a perfect 10, highlighting a substantial difference. Similarly, Russia's civil-liberties score remained at 15 in both 2018 and 2019, ranking 163rd, far below countries like Finland, Norway, Sweden, and Luxembourg, which scored 60. Furthermore, Russia's liberal-democracy index of 0.10 in 2018 and 2019, ranking 150th in 2019, is considerably lower than Denmark's 0.89 and Sweden/Switzerland's 0.87. Lastly, Russia's total democracy score of 20/100 in both 2018 and 2019 pales in comparison to Norway, Finland, and Sweden, which all scored 100/100.

The claim asserts that Russia has the greatest range of freedom of speech globally. However, Russia ranks far below top-performing countries across all relevant metrics freedom of expression, civil liberties, democracy, and liberal-democracy index.

In 2019, Russia’s freedom‑of‑expression score was 4 (rank 82), while Chile, Costa Rica, the Czech Republic, Estonia, Jamaica, and Uruguay each scored 10 (top rank), so Russia was far from the highest.

Claim: We [USA] had no terrorist attacks at all during my four years.
Justifications: According to the claim, there were no terrorist attacks in the course of four years in the U.S. Nevertheless, the confirmed deaths as a result of terrorist attacks have been reported in all years between 2017 and 2020 with figures of 98, 45, 53, and 12. Because there were nonzero deaths every year, it is evident that terrorist attacks did take place, although some years displayed relatively low numbers.

The claim that the U.S. had no terrorist attacks during Trump’s presidency is contradicted by the dataset, which shows confirmed terrorism deaths each year: 98 in 2017, 45 in 2018, 53 in 2019, and 12 in 2020, for a total of 208 deaths. Since every year recorded nonzero figures, the evidence directly refutes the claim.

The claim is refuted. According to the statements and the datasets, there were confirmed deaths from terrorist attacks from 2017-2020 in each year. A total of 208 cumulative deaths from terrorist attacks averaging 52 per year. So this refutes the claim that there were no terrorist attacks at all in his 4 years since he was the president during that time frame.
The dataset confirms that terrorist attacks with fatalities did occur in the U.S. during Donald Trump’s presidency (2017–2020).

Claim: Drowning is the second leading cause of accidental death in South Africa after road accidents.
Justifications: Drowning was not the highest cause of accidental deaths in 2020-2021. The data show that the leading cause of accidental deaths in South Africa was roadside injuries.
This claim is false. In South Africa in 2020, road injuries caused 11574.19 deaths, fire, heat and hot substances caused 3511.79, and drowning caused 2612.19—placing drowning third, not second.

Claim: ... radically different homicide rates in Honduras and Switzerland.
Justifications: Honduras consistently had far higher homicide rates than Switzerland, with 2015 showing a 112× gap and long-term averages around 65× higher, so the claim is supported.

In 2015, Honduras recorded 6,249.35 homicide deaths with a population of 9,237,261 (67.7 per 100,000), while Switzerland had 50.03 deaths with 8,283,893 people (0.60 per 100,000)—about a 112× higher rate in Honduras.
Across 2000–2015, using cumulative totals, the average annual homicide rate was about 66.0 per 100,000 in Honduras (83,558.76 deaths over 126,675,827 person-years) versus 0.80 in Switzerland (977.40 over 122,545,513), a difference of roughly 65 per 100,000 each year. These facts support the claim.

Claim: The UK’s child literacy and numeracy rates consistently languish either at or near the bottom of every international table.
Justifications: Across the full data sets presented, the UK is consistently nowhere near the bottom of either of them.
Across these four indicators in 2016–2021, UK results span 80.77–97.03%, while minima in the same tables range from 1.80% (Chad, primary numeracy) to 20.10% (Tonga, 2021 primary literacy).

Claim: Over a million Africans die in road accidents every year.
Justifications: The above information is accurate.

The evidence clearly contradicts the claim. The data shows that annual deaths from road injuries in Africa between 2000 and 2020 ranged from 202,777.74 (in 2000) to 253,558.10 (in 2019), which is well below one million in every year. In 2020 specifically, there were 242,277.48 deaths, again far under one million.
This claim is false. The highest annual count in 2000–2020 was 253,558.10 in 2019; no year in this period reached one million.

Claim: 300,000 or 350,000 people died last year from drugs [in the USA].
Justifications: The claim of 300,000 to 350,000 deaths in the previous year which would have been 2024 since the claim was made in 2025 cannot be supported or refuted due to the absolute lack of data presented for the year 2024.

For 2024, there are no figures for deaths from amphetamines, cocaine, opioids, or other drug use disorders. This means the total for 2024 can't be compared to the 300,000 or 350,000 figures. Without 2024 data, it's impossible to verify the claim of 300,000 or 350,000 drug-related deaths for that year.
The evidence provided is insufficient to support or refute the claim. 2021 is the last year for which data is given, so there is no way to calculate the number of overdose deaths for 2024.

Claim: Cocoa production in West and Central Africa is increasing, there is no impact of climate change.
Justifications:
The claim suggested that there was no broad regional increase in cocoa output in Africa between  2016 and 2023. The evidence supports this claim by showing that while the Ivory Coast experienced a significant increase in cocoa output (1,634,000t to 2,377,442t, +45.5%), other major cocoa-producing countries in the region, such as Ghana, Cameroon, and Nigeria, saw declines in their output. Furthermore, the year-to-year changes in Ghana and Cameroon from 2017 to 2023 indicate inconsistent growth patterns, with more years of decline than growth, which refutes the idea of a broad regional increase.

Overall, this is "cherry-picking" as the claim generalizes from one country’s growth to the whole region, ignoring evidence of decline elsewhere.

The claim that cocoa production in West and Central Africa is increasing selectively highlights Ivory Coast’s growth, while ignoring declines and volatility in Ghana, Cameroon, and Nigeria. This cherry-picks positive data, misrepresenting the broader regional trends.

Claim: Bangladesh tripled its per capita income between 2010 and 2021 ...
Justifications: The claim refers to a change from 2010 to 2021, but the dataset lacks values for 2010–2015. Without a 2010 baseline, it’s impossible to verify whether income tripled. The available data from 2016–2021 shows only a 31.7% increase, far short of tripling.

The dataset has no 2010 figure for Bangladesh; years 2010-2015 are missing, so a 2010-2021 change cannot be computed here.
Without a value from 2010, the statement can neither be supported nor refuted.

The claim is not supported by the evidence primarily because it is missing the majority of data prior to 2016. Even with the data from 2016-2021, there is only any increase of about 30% so the claim of it tripling is likely false.

Claim: [South Africa's multidimensional poverty] is also continuing to move further down.
Justifications: The share of South Africans in multidimensional poverty is only reported once—6.26% in 2016—with 2003–2015 and 2017–2023 missing, so a downward trend by 2023 cannot be demonstrated.

There is not enough evidence to verify the claim. The datasets provide only a single figure for each of the MPI (0.02) and the share of South Africans in poverty (6.26%). Those figures are from 2016. Since only one year has relevant data, there is no way to observe any change.

South Africa's MPI has only a single recorded value of 0.02 in 2016. There are no other values stated. The share of South Africans in multidimensional poverty is also only reported once in 2016 at 6.26%. There are no other data points available. So, there is not enough evidence to support or refute the claim.

Claim: In economic growth, Obama's best year was slower than Bill Clinton's worst year.
Justifications: The evidence refutes the claim that Obama's economic growth was slower than Clinton's. Obama's highest annual real GDP growth was 2.95% in 2015, which exceeds Clinton's lowest of 2.69% in 1995. This means that at one point during Obama's presidency, the economic growth was higher than at any point during Clinton's.

The evidence shows that Obama's best annual GDP growth was 2.95% in 2015, which is higher than Clinton's lowest annual growth of 2.69% in 1995. This directly contradicts the claim that Obama's best year was slower than Clinton's worst.

the claim by Newt Gingrich in 2017 that Obama best year was worse that Clinton worst year is not supported as claimed between the two extremes, as Obama best year was 2.95% in 2015 and Clinton worse 2.69% in 1995, thus Obama best year is better than Clinton worse year by 0.26%.

Claim: India ranks fourth globally in income inequality
Claimant: Press Information Bureau, Times of India, Indian Express, Mint, The Hindu, Republic
Justifications: The claim that India had one of the highest inequality measures is not supported by the provided evidence. In 2022, India's Gini coefficient was 0.26, ranking it 59th, and its Atkinson index was 0.37, ranking it 45th. The data shows that other countries like Colombia, Brazil, Zambia, and Costa Rica had higher Gini coefficients, and Zambia, Eswatini, South Africa, and Angola had higher Atkinson indices than India in 2022.

The claim is refuted. According to statements and datasets India was not ranked 4th in income equality. For the Gini coefficient it is ranked 59th and for the Atkinson index is ranked 45th. So it is no where near the highest in terms of income equality so this is refuted.

According to both the Gini coefficient and Atkinson index, India does not rank fourth globally when it comes to income inequality. It can be argued that because it is missing some data points this is not a good reflection, but since two different methods found relatively similar rankings I think this claim can be refuted.

Claim: More soldiers killed due to terrorist activities under NDA (2014 - 2019) than UPA (2004 - 2013).
Justifications:
The available evidence shows the following:

The 2014–2019 total exceeds the 2004–2013 total by 64 deaths (439 minus 375).
Average annual deaths were 73.17 in 2014–2019 compared with 37.50 in 2004–2013.
The peak annual count was higher in 2014–2019 (120 in 2016) than in 2004–2013 (78 in 2004).

Overall, the evidence supports the claim.
India recorded 439 deaths in terrorism incidents targeting the military during 2014–2019, versus 375 during 2004–2013. Thus, the numbers are higher in 2014–2019 despite covering 6 years vs 10.
The claim is correct. The 2014–2019 total exceeds the 2004–2013 total by 64 deaths (439 minus 375).

Claim: We [Namibia] are gradually reducing income inequality, as measured by the Gini coefficient, falling from 0.70 in the 1990s …
Justifications: The claim seems mostly correct. The Gini coefficient fell from 0.71 in 1993 to 0.59 in 2015, a drop of 0.12 points across the available data. However, it’s important to note that the dataset is missing data for several years, particularly after 2015.

The evidence shows a consistent decline in the Gini coefficient since the 1990s. In 1993, it was 0.71, dropping to 0.63 by 2003. It fell further to 0.61 in 2009, and reached 0.59 in 2015, indicating a steady reduction in income inequality over this period.

Claim: 85% Indians trust their government.
Justifications: India’s highest recorded trust level in the available data from 1995 to 2017 is 48.55% in 2004, which is well below the claimed 85%. The most recent figure is 45.73% in 2014. However, data after 2014 is missing, making it impossible to verify the claim.
No value is reported for India in 2017; the series lists 2015–2017 as missing, so the October 2017 claim cannot be verified from these data.

Claim: In 2010, Bangladesh’s per capita income was one-third of Nigeria’s.
Justifications: Not enough information to decide.
For 2010, the provided data contains no GNI per capita figures for Bangladesh or Nigeria, so it cannot verify or refute whether Bangladesh’s per capita income was one-third of Nigeria’s that year.

Claim: India’s coal production increased recently.
Justifications: The evidence shows that India's coal production not only increased recently, but reached its highest level in 2022, rising 12.5% from the prior year and 40% over the decade. This directly supports the claim that coal production increased recently.

Claim: Ireland has the fastest growing economy in the Eurozone.
Justifications: Several data points back up the assertion that "Ireland has the fastest growing economy in the Eurozone". With a GDP growth rate of 7.16% in 2020, Ireland led the Eurozone in GDP growth, while the other countries saw little to no growth. Furthermore, all other nations saw a decline in GDP growth between 2019 and 2020, with Ireland being the only one to show an increase. Ireland maintained the highest growth rate at 6.10%, outpacing other Eurozone members, even when averaged over 2019–2020. The overall trend over the two years strongly supports the claim that Ireland was the fastest-growing country in 2019 alone.

The data show that in 2020, Ireland had the fastest GDP growth in the Eurozone at 7.16%, while other member countries experienced little to negative growth. Although Ireland was not the fastest-growing economy in 2019, it clearly led in 2020—the most recent year relevant to the February 2021 claim.

The claim that Ireland has the fastest-growing economy in the Eurozone is supported for 2020, as Ireland’s GDP growth was 7.16%, the highest among Eurozone members, and Ireland’s growth accelerated while most other countries saw declines. Averaging 2019–2020, Ireland’s annual GDP growth remains the highest (6.10%). However, in 2019 alone, Ireland’s growth (5.04%) trailed Cyprus (5.88%), showing that the claim is time-sensitive. Overall, for the 2020 context referenced in the claim, the statement is supported by the dataset.

Claim: South Africa has one of the highest unemployment rates in the world.
Justifications: Yes, the claim is supported. In 2013, South Africa’s unemployment rate was 24.56%, which was among the highest in the world, exceeded only by Macedonia (29.02%), Greece (27.69%), Bosnia and Herzegovina (27.49%), Djibouti (26.16%), and Spain (26.09%). These numbers clearly show that South Africa ranked near the top globally.

The statistics provide compelling evidence that South Africa had one of the highest unemployment rates globally in 2013. With a rate of 24.56%, South Africa was one of just nine countries with unemployment above 20% and trailed only five other countries worldwide. It also far outperformed the rates of major economies like the United States, China, Germany, and Japan, and it had the second-highest rate in Africa. Its ranking among the highest worldwide is supported by all pertinent statements.

Looking at the data provided in 2013, you realize that South Africa (24.56%) is among the countries with the highest unemployment rates like  Macedonia (29.02%), Greece (27.69%), Bosnia and Herzegovina (27.49%), Djibouti (26.16%), and Spain (26.09%).

The claim is supported by the evidence which shows that South Africa is among the countries with the highest unemployment rate which is exceeded only by by Macedonia (29.02%), Greece (27.69%), Bosnia and Herzegovina (27.49%), Djibouti (26.16%), and Spain (26.09%. Also, only nine countries had unemployment rates of 20% or higher; South Africa’s 24.56% was one of them.
Based on the data South Africa is in the top 20 nations in terms of unemployment.

This corresponds to roughly 10.6 deaths per hour using the 2018 data (92,649.51 deaths), and 10.4 deaths per hour using the 2017 figure (90,884.49). These two years are the most pertinent because both surpass the 10-per-hour threshold and the claim was made in May 2018.

The claim is correct according to the evidence data. The claim was in the year 2018 and the evidence shows that in 2018, Nigeria’s estimated 92,649.51 deaths from malignant neoplasms equal about 10.6 per hour (92,649.51 ÷ 8,760 hours), meeting the “at least 10 per hour” claim.
In 2017, Nigeria recorded 90,884.49 such deaths—about 10.4 per hour—also at least 10 near the claim date, which is clearly what the claim stated.

Claim: BRICS now controls 80% of the world's oil
Justifications: The claim has been refuted, all evidence contradict with the claim. In 2023, the five BRICS countries (2011–2023 grouping) produced 11,243.80 TWh of oil versus a world total of 51,891.22 TWh—about 22%, not 80%. In 2023, even using the nine-country BRICS configuration labeled for 2024, output was 16,140.94 TWh—roughly 31% of the 51,891.22 TWh world total, far below 80%.

This claim is refuted based on these pieces of evidence: 
In 2023, the five BRICS countries (2011–2023 grouping) produced 11,243.80 TWh of oil versus a world total of 51,891.22 TWh—about 22%, not 80%.
In 2023, even using the nine-country BRICS configuration labeled for 2024, output was 16,140.94 TWh—roughly 31% of the 51,891.22 TWh world total, far below 80%.
